newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary starts 3rd wave of simplified privatisations.
newsitem.headline: Hungary starts 3rd wave of simplified privatisations.

text.p: Hungary's privatisation agency APV Rt has announced on Tuesday the third and last wave of simplified privatisation involving 19 companies with a total of 2.4 billion forints state stake.
"We are expecting primarily domestic investors," APV director Maria Matyi told a news conference.
She added that under the simplified procedure the offered price is the only criterion, with neither the successful bidders nor APV having any further obligations once the sale is completed.

In the first two waves of the simplified privatisation, Hungary sold state stakes in 121 companies with a total nominal value of 17.8 billion forints for 8.88 billion forints or an average 51 percent of the nominal price.

The simplified procedure differs from the regular selloff system in that it involves no employment, production, environmental or other commitments on the buyers' side and no after-sale obligations on APV's side.
The minimum price set in the present stage is an average 50 percent of the nominal value, Matyi said.
The limit prices range from 500,000 forints to 300 million forints, she said.
Under the amended privatisation law, companies with a maximum 800 million forints share capital and fewer than 500 employees can qualify for the simplified procedure.
Bidders have to deposit 25 percent of the limit price.
Bids can be submitted on July 2 and APV will evaluate them within 30 days thereafter, Matyi said.
